Task.Name: Word completion given part of word
Task.Writeup:
Word completion given part of word


1. Set-Up

A set of 36 words with 2-3 letters missing (ex.“ _ ech_ _ que” would be “technique”)


2. Objective / Goal

To complete as many words as possible

Task.Name: Ravens Matrices
Task.Writeup:
Ravens Matrices


1. Set-Up

Participants are presented with a pattern, which usually looks like a matrix or grid with a white background. There is a missing piece to the pattern.


2. Objective / Goal

The goal is to complete the pattern by identifying what the missing piece should be. The problem is multiple-choice, so participants will choose just one correct answer from a variety of options.

Task.Name: Euclidean traveling salesperson
Task.Writeup:
Euclidean traveling salesperson


1. Set-Up

Participants get a map with multiple cities, which are displayed as dots on the screen. These dots can be connected by different “paths” by clicking on two dots one after the other. For example, clicking on point A, then point B, would draw a “path” between A and B.


2. Objective / Goal

The goal is to find and select a sequence of cities corresponding to the shortest possible path to traverse through all of the cities, forming a cycle (or loop). In other words, the participant should click through the dots in a sequence, thus drawing a path that touches every city exactly once, and the first city twice: you can think of it as a “traveling salesman” who visits each city on the map before returning to his home city. Imagine that the shortest path involves going from A, to B, to C, to D. In that example, the participant’s goal would be to find this path, and then click the cities in that order: A, B, C, D, A.

Task.Name: 9 Dot Problem
Task.Writeup:
9 Dot Problem


1. Set-Up

Participants are given a 3x3 grid of nine dots.


2. Objective / Goal

Participants must connect all nine dots (e.g., draw a line that passes through them) using no more than four lines, and may not retrace any lines.

Task.Name: Moral Reasoning (Disciplinary Action Case)
Task.Writeup:
Moral Reasoning (Disciplinary Action Case)


1. Set-Up

Participants read a fictitious, controversial case in which a college basketball player bribed an instructor to change his grade on an exam, to maintain his eligibility on the team.

Participants are also given a list of potential issues, in which the student and/or instructor could be given a punishment or consequence. Examples include:

(1.) Student's Grade (2.) Student Suspension (3.) Student's Basketball Team (4.) Instructor Punishment (5.) Instructor Future Position


2. Objective / Goal

To agree on one choice from a list of alternatives for each issue having to do with the treatment of the athlete and the instructor.

Task.Name: Summarize Discussion
Task.Writeup:
Summarize Discussion


1. Set-Up

For this task, participants are given a discussion statement about a specific topic. The statement may be a question like “what makes for success in our culture”


2. Objective / Goal

Participants are asked to discuss the statement and submit responses to the discussion statement.

Task.Name: Letters-to-numbers problems (cryptography)
Task.Writeup:
Letters-to-numbers problems (cryptography)


1. Set-Up

Participants are given a series of mathematical problems (for example, 3+5), except the numbers have been replaced with letters! So, instead of 3+5, users would instead see “A+B”, where the letter “A” maps to “3” and “B” maps to “5”.

Paricipants will also have the opportunity to see the answers to certain problems. For example, 3+5 = 8; maybe the number “8” maps to the letter “C.” In the case, the participant would have the information that A + B = C.


2. Objective / Goal

The objective was to identify the mapping of the 10 letters to the 10 numbers in as few trials as possible.

Task.Name: Word completion given starting letter
Task.Writeup:
Word completion given starting letter


1. Set-Up

Participants are given a starting letter and ending letter for words. For example, the start letter could be “S” and the end letter could be “N.” The starting and ending letters are selected such that there is always a nonzero set of English words that can be created.


2. Objective / Goal

The goal is to generate a list of valid English words using the starting and ending letter provided. Using the previous example, participants could be asked to generate words like “SPIN,” which starts with “S” and ends with “N.” Participants must generate the maximum number of valid words they can within a fixed amount of time. Nonvalid words will be rejected by the system.

Task.Name: Allocating resources to programs
Task.Writeup:
Allocating resources to programs


1. Set-Up

Partipants are given a list of several complex social projects, along with details of those projects. The following are examples of proposed projects:

(1.) To purchase a new computer system for the county government in order to hold local taxes constant. (2.) To establish a community arts program featuring art, music, and dance programs for children and adults. (3.) To establish an additional shelter for the homeless in the community.


2. Objective / Goal

The goal is to decide how to allocate $500,000 between these competing projects.

Task.Name: Image rating
Task.Writeup:
Image rating


1. Set-Up

Pictures of a series of products and accompanying slogans


2. Objective / Goal

To rate slogans on a scale of 1 (worst) to 10 (best) based on what they believed a large sample of Americans would rate their suitability for the given products

Task.Name: To evacuate or not to evacuate
Task.Writeup:
To evacuate or not to evacuate


1. Set-Up

Participants read about a situation in which 'a disaster may or may not strike.' Different variations could have different wordings — for example, in which the disaster is presented to be more or less serious, or more or less certain. Participants will also be given additional relevant information, such as the expected damage and cost of the disaster.


2. Objective / Goal

The goal is to make a decision regarding whether to evacuate from an impending disaster that would wipe out subjects' endowment unless they evacuated in time.

Task.Name: Wildcat Wells
Task.Writeup:
Wildcat Wells


1. Set-Up

Participants see a map of an oil well (called Wildcat Wells).


2. Objective / Goal

The goal of the game is to “drill for oil”. Participants earn points by searching for the hidden oil fields, with the goal of finding the most oil.

Task.Name: Estimating pages of a book
Task.Writeup:
Estimating pages of a book


1. Set-Up

Images of books' page edges


2. Objective / Goal

To judge the number of pages in books based on images of their page edges

Task.Name: Recall videos
Task.Writeup:
Recall videos


1. Set-Up

A 90-second video


2. Objective / Goal

To answer a set of questions about what occurred in the video

Task.Name: Graph coloring task
Task.Writeup:
Graph coloring task


1. Set-Up

Participants are given one or more “graph coloring problems”. These are pictures of different topology/network graphs.

For context, these look like many different nodes (points), which are connected by various edges. Imagine, for example, a picture of a social network: each person in the network is a “node,” and each of their friends is an “edge.”

In this case, all participants have access to and can interact with a shared graph. Participants will also be given a limited set of colors, with a larger number of colors than the minimum required to complete the task successfully.


2. Objective / Goal

The goal is to use the colors given to “color” the entire network without conflicts. This means that participants need to assign each node in the graph a color, ensuring that no two connected nodes share the same color. Using our social network example, if Person A and Person B are friends (which means they are connected), they cannot be assigned the same color. Participants must successfully color all nodes and resolve all conflicts within a specified amount of time, or receive no credit.

Task.Name: Shopping plan
Task.Writeup:
Shopping plan


1. Set-Up

Each participant has a grocery list and a map that shows distances and times between each grocery store, as well as a list of potential items to purchase and how many points they are worth.


2. Objective / Goal

Participants have to plan a shopping trip as though they were all residents of the same house sharing the same car. The goal is to purchase as many high-quality items as possible in a fixed amount of time, and to get the highest number of points by considering tradeoffs between price, quality, and driving time. Participants gain points for every item that they are able to purchase.

Task.Name: Abstract grid task
Task.Writeup:
Abstract grid task


1. Set-Up

Participants were given a grid, in which some squares in the grid were colored in, and other squares in the grid were not colored in. The grid was interactive, and offered the opportunity to change the squares' colors by either “adding” color where a square was not filled in, or “substracting” color where a square was already filled in (removing the color from the square).


2. Objective / Goal

The goal was to make the grid appear symmetrical from left-to-right and top-to-bottom using the fewest number of clicks. (Each click represented one manipulation — either adding or subtracting color from the grid.)

Task.Name: Advertisement writing
Task.Writeup:
Advertisement writing


1. Set-Up

Participants were given the description of a product from Kickstarter.


2. Objective / Goal

The goal was to write an online text advertisement no more than 30 characters for product campaigns from Kickstarter.

Task.Name: Guessing the correlation
Task.Writeup:
Guessing the correlation


1. Set-Up

Participants received a series of scatter plots (a series of points plotted on a grid).


2. Objective / Goal

The goal was to estimate the correlation of the points on the grid. (For example, if all the dots are in a straight line pointing upwards, the correlation is 1; if the dots are completely scattered randomly with no pattern at all, the correlation is 0).

Task.Name: Whac-A-Mole
Task.Writeup:
Whac-A-Mole


1. Set-Up

Participants were given a screen with a bunch of colored moving targets (circles) and an ability to click or “hit” the targets as they moved around.


2. Objective / Goal

Participants' goal was to hit targets based on their point value, thereby maximizing their points. They also had to reach their targets more quickly than an opponent (i.e., try to beat them by hitting more targets and getting more points).

Task.Name: Putting food into categories
Task.Writeup:
Putting food into categories


1. Set-Up

To investigate the impact of membership change on group creativity, study compares the creativity level of an open group, where members rotate through twenty two teams of three to that of a closed group, where the members remain the same.


2. Objective / Goal

Divide a list of 12 fruits or vegetables into categories.

Task.Name: Room assignment task
Task.Writeup:
Room assignment task


1. Set-Up

Participants are given a set of people (students), rooms, and rules (constraining conditions).


2. Objective / Goal

The goal is to assign students to rooms within a fixed amount of time in order to maximize the students' utility as much as possible while also respecting all of the constraining conditions (for example, one rule might say that certain people are not allowed to be in the same room). Students get a specified amount of utility from being assigned to a particular room, which translates to points in the game.

Participants will be shown the running total of how many points their current submission has earned, but they will not be notified if they have achieved the optimal arrangement. If participants' submission violates some of the contraining conditions, they will receive a score penalty.

Task.Name: Divergent Association Task
Task.Writeup:
Divergent Association Task


1. Set-Up

Participants are given a blank space to write 10 words in.


2. Objective / Goal

Come up with 10 nouns as different from each other as possible in four minutes.

Task.Name: Recall association
Task.Writeup:
Recall association


1. Set-Up

Participants are given a list of words to study.


2. Objective / Goal

Recall as many words as possible from the studied list.

Task.Name: Search for Oil Task
Task.Writeup:
Search for Oil Task


1. Set-Up

Pariticipants view a grid with 144 sections of land, represented by a 12 by 12 matrix on a 80-cm by 80-cm board. Some of these grids are “suitable” for drilling oil, and others are not. During the task, participants receive feedback about their decisions to drill; if a decision was correct, a red dot will appear on the screen. Otherwise, the part of the screen remains blank.


2. Objective / Goal

The goal of the task is to decide which of 144 sections of land is suitable for drilling oil, and to do so as accurately as possible (make recommendations about places where there is actually oil).

Task.Name: Wolf, goat and cabbage transfer
Task.Writeup:
Wolf, goat and cabbage transfer


1. Set-Up

The problem reads as follows:

“Once upon a time a farmer went to a market and purchased a wolf, a goat, and a cabbage. On his way home, the farmer came to the bank of a river and rented a boat. But crossing the river by boat, the farmer could carry only himself and a single one of his purchases: the wolf, the goat, or the cabbage.

If left unattended together, the wolf would eat the goat, or the goat would eat the cabbage.

The farmer's challenge was to carry himself and his purchases to the far bank of the river, leaving each purchase intact. How did he do it?”


2. Objective / Goal

Participants had to solve the problem by devising a way to move the wolf, goat, and cabbage from one river bank to another in the fewest trips.

Task.Name: Putting food into categories-2
Task.Writeup:
Putting food into categories


1. Set-Up

Participants were provided with a list containing several (e.g., a dozen) fruit and vegetable items (e.g., orange, grapes).


2. Objective / Goal

The goal was to generate different categories that could divide the food items. They had to come up with as many criteria as they could to classify the items into subgroups (e.g., citrus vs non-citrus, tropical vs non-tropical).

Task.Name: Whac-A-Mole-2
Task.Writeup:
Whac-A-Mole


1. Set-Up

Participants were given a screen with a bunch of colored moving targets (circles) and an ability to click or “hit” the targets as they moved around.


2. Objective / Goal

Participants' goal was to hit targets based on their point value, thereby maximizing their points.

Task.Name: Husbands and wives transfer
Task.Writeup:
Husbands and wives transfer


1. Set-Up

Participants received the Tartaglia Transportation puzzle and six questions regarding their previous exposure to it.


2. Objective / Goal

The goal was to answer questions about previous exposure to the puzzle, estimate whether one can solve it in 45 minutes, and then try to solve it.

Task.Name: Recall images
Task.Writeup:
Recall images


1. Set-Up

Image test: images of target faces and sets of facesWord test: list of target words and sets of words Story test: short paragraphs and a number of multiple-choice questions about the paragraphs


2. Objective / Goal

The goal of the task is to memorize different types of stimuli: words, images, and stories and identify the targets words/images/stories

Task.Name: Railroad Route Construction game
Task.Writeup:
Railroad Route Construction game


1. Set-Up

A game to create train track routes by moving the railroad pieces to the right positions


2. Objective / Goal

The goal of the task is to test whether the robot’s vulnerability would help to ease group tension and facilitate positive group dynamics.

Task.Name: Estimating geological metrics
Task.Writeup:
Estimating geological metrics


1. Set-Up

Participants are given a series of prompts -Estimate the following quantities:1. Number of miles from New York to Los Angeles2. Average weight of an elephant3. Number of U.S. states that border the Gulf of Mexico4. Number of months per year residents of Tromoso, Norway go without seeing a sunset5. Highest temperature (in degrees F) ever registered in the U.S.6. Number of miles from New York to Los Angeles7. Average weight of an elephant8. Number of U.S. states that border the Gulf of Mexico9. Number of months per year residents of Tromoso, Norway go without seeing a sunset10. Highest temperature (in degrees F) ever registered in the U.S.


2. Objective / Goal

To correctly answer a series of questions without looking up the solutions online

Task.Name: The Fish game
Task.Writeup:
The Fish game


1. Set-Up

A game board where the player can move his avatar and see the corresponding scores to the current location (the avatar is at)


2. Objective / Goal

The goal is to move the avatar to achieve the highest score.

Task.Name: Estimating social quantity
Task.Writeup:
Estimating social quantity


1. Set-Up

A set of questions requiring estimation of a quantity (e.g., “What was the median age in the U.S. in 2009?”)


2. Objective / Goal

To answer questions requiring the estimation of a quantity in real life as many as possible (out of the question sets given).

Task.Name: Find the maximum
Task.Writeup:
Find the maximum


1. Set-Up

Images of some math functions (relationships between input and output)


2. Objective / Goal

To correctly guess the maximum value of a function after a limited number of guesses and feedback

Task.Name: Visual Oddball Target
Task.Writeup:
Visual Oddball Target


1. Set-Up

Participants had monitors in front of them on which visual stimuli were presented and either a mouse or a keyboard.


2. Objective / Goal

The goal was to decide in which interval the target appeared on the screen by pressing a button on a mouse or a keyboard.

Task.Name: Checkers
Task.Writeup:
Checkers


1. Set-Up

Participants were seated in front of a computer.


2. Objective / Goal

The goal was to play checkers in a group against a computer.

Task.Name: Reproducing arts
Task.Writeup:
Reproducing arts


1. Set-Up

Participants were given an online spreadsheet tool and a hard copy of a colored spreadsheet.


2. Objective / Goal

The goal was to reproduce a colored spreadsheet in 10 minutes.

Task.Name: Computer maze
Task.Writeup:
Computer maze


1. Set-Up

Participants were given a computer monitor with a virtual maze environment and either a keyboard or a joystick.


2. Objective / Goal

The goal was to tag as many identical “greeble” pairs in the computer-based maze as possible out of six identical and six distracting greebles.

Task.Name: Categorization problem
Task.Writeup:
Categorization problem


1. Set-Up

Participants received a categorization problem consisting of sixteen cards forming five squares with two objects each.


2. Objective / Goal

The goal was to form four groups of items with no cards left unused.

Task.Name: Recall stories
Task.Writeup:
Recall stories


1. Set-Up

Participants received two stories four pages each. 12 questions accompanied each story.


2. Objective / Goal

The goal was to read two short stories in 10 minutes and answer knowledge questions about them.

Task.Name: Hidden figures in a picture
Task.Writeup:
Hidden figures in a picture


1. Set-Up

Participants received 10 puzzle pictures containing hidden animals with names of four target animals.


2. Objective / Goal

The goal was to point at target animals in puzzle pictures.

Task.Name: Word construction from a subset of letters
Task.Writeup:
Word construction from a subset of letters


1. Set-Up

Participants were presented with nine letters.


2. Objective / Goal

The goal was to produce as many four letter words as possible from a given set of nine letters.

Task.Name: Trivia Multiple Choice Quiz
Task.Writeup:
Trivia Multiple Choice Quiz


1. Set-Up

Participants received a series of multiple choice trivia questions.


2. Objective / Goal

The goal was to correctly answer a series of multiple choice questions without looking them up online.

Task.Name: Logic Problem
Task.Writeup:
Logic Problem


1. Set-Up

Participants received either a logic problem or 33 anagrams ranging from 5 to 14 letters.


2. Objective / Goal

The goal was to complete either a logic problem or 33 anagrams in 5 minutes.

Task.Name: Writing story
Task.Writeup:
Writing story


1. Set-Up

Participants received a writing prompt.


2. Objective / Goal

The goal was to write a response to a question in the group.

Task.Name: 5 squares problem
Task.Writeup:
5 squares problem


1. Set-Up

Participants were given 16 cards with images.


2. Objective / Goal

The goal was to group 16 cards into four categories.

Task.Name: Target Search
Task.Writeup:
Target Search


1. Set-Up

Participants could view a labeled board with 100 three-inch squares which corresponded to values on a diagram the experimenter had.


2. Objective / Goal

The goals was to collectively guess coordinates and value of the diagram on a labeled board.

Task.Name: Moving offices (complex task)
Task.Writeup:
Moving offices (complex task)


1. Set-Up

Participants received a card with a problem statement and a card with a piece of information needed to solve the problem.


2. Objective / Goal

The goal was to solve the problem by exchanging information with group members through message notes.

Task.Name: Wason’s Selection Task
Task.Writeup:
Wason’s Selection Task


1. Set-Up

Participants were given two cards with conditional sentences and eight cards with colored geometric shapes on one side and scribble on another front side up in a random array.


2. Objective / Goal

The goal was to select a card that proved the given conditional sentence false.

Task.Name: Desert survival
Task.Writeup:
Desert survival


1. Set-Up

Participants viewed a video describing a survival scenario in which a plane crashes in the desert and various items (e.g., water, machete, compass, and cosmetic mirror) are salvaged from the wreckage.


2. Objective / Goal

The goal was to rank 16 items in the order of most to least importance for survival.

Task.Name: The N light bulbs game
Task.Writeup:
The N light bulbs game


1. Set-Up

Participants viewed an NK-landscape with 10 dimensions representing 10 lightbulbs that could be either turned on or off.


2. Objective / Goal

The goal was to turn lightbulbs on or off to get the highest payoff.

Task.Name: The maximum of a function
Task.Writeup:
The maximum of a function


1. Set-Up

The participants worked in a visual interface through which they guessed function's maximum and received its outputs. Functions were hidden from participants.


2. Objective / Goal

The goal was to find the maximum of a complex function.

Task.Name: Reading the mind in the eyes
Task.Writeup:
Reading the mind in the eyes


1. Set-Up

Participants were given 36 pairs of eyes.


2. Objective / Goal

The goal was to choose one of four words describing the emotion.

Task.Name: Iterative lemonade stand task
Task.Writeup:
Iterative lemonade stand task


1. Set-Up

Participants are given an excel program that allows users to tweak five variables (price, lemon content, sugar content, color and location or a lemonade cart).


2. Objective / Goal

The goal is to maximize the cart's revenue by adjusting given variables.

Task.Name: Random dot motion
Task.Writeup:
Random dot motion


1. Set-Up

Participants were exposed to 50 moving dots on a computer screen with some dots moving moving consistently in similar direction and other in random directions.


2. Objective / Goal

The goal was to determine the main direction of dots with correlated movement.

Task.Name: Crisis mapping
Task.Writeup:
Crisis mapping


1. Set-Up

Participants were given a collection of pre-processed 1567 tweets about Typhoon Pablo posted on December 4th and 5th.


2. Objective / Goal

The goal was to collect relevant tweets and geo-locate, time-stamp, and categorize damage/flooding photos and videos in them to create a crisis map for Typhoon Pablo.

Task.Name: Game of Clue - Terrorist Attack
Task.Writeup:
Game of Clue - Terrorist Attack


1. Set-Up

Participants worked in a Web platform that allowed to communicate regarding clues in a 'who-done-it' game like Clue or Cluedo, but with a terrorist attack.


2. Objective / Goal

The goal was to solve: (a) who would carry out the terrorist attack, (b) what would be the target, © where the attack would take place, and (d) when the attack would take place.

Task.Name: Sudoku
Task.Writeup:
Sudoku


1. Set-Up

Participants were given a computer with a shared online system which included a sudoku puzzle and in-built chat window.


2. Objective / Goal

The goal was to solve a sudoku puzzle so that every row, every column, and every 3x3 box of 9x9 grid has the digits 1-9 only once.

Task.Name: Judgment of product and slogan
Task.Writeup:
Judgment of product and slogan


1. Set-Up

Participants received a series of products and accompanying slogans in a shared online system viewed on laptop computer.


2. Objective / Goal

The goal was to to rate slogans on a scale of 1 (worst) to 10 (best) based on what participants believed to be a large sample of what Americans would rate their suitability for the given products.

Task.Name: Unscramble words (anagrams)
Task.Writeup:
Unscramble words (anagrams)


1. Set-Up

Participants received a list of 24 randomly scrambled words.


2. Objective / Goal

The goal was to unscramble as many words from the list as possible in two minutes.

Task.Name: Recall word lists
Task.Writeup:
Recall word lists


1. Set-Up

Participants received a list of words recorded on audio tape by a male voice at the rate of one word per second with an auditory cue recall recorded after the last word of each list.


2. Objective / Goal

The goal was to remember the lists of words and then write down as many words from the list in any order but starting with the last word.

Task.Name: Architectural design task
Task.Writeup:
Architectural design task


1. Set-Up

Participants received written and video instruction of building task and scoring information.


2. Objective / Goal

The goal was to design a house, a garage, and a pool from a limited set of building blocks, adhering to provided rules for each building.

Task.Name: Space Fortress
Task.Writeup:
Space Fortress


1. Set-Up

Participants received a computer screen with a video game, headphones with sound effects, a joystick and a trigger to control a space ship.


2. Objective / Goal

The goal was to gain as many points as possible by launching missiles from spaceship, destroying a space fortress and avoiding damage.
